thread.title: Russian Spy Ship Spotted Off The Coast Of Delaware
thread.title_full: Russian Spy Ship Spotted Off The Coast Of Delaware

author: Fred Maxwell
title: Russian Spy Ship Spotted Off The Coast Of Delaware
text:
Russian Spy Ship Spotted Off The Coast Of Delaware "... not at all out of the ordinary." by Fred Maxwell February 14, 2017 at 2:47pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Fox News reported Tuesday that a Russian spy ship has been seen approximately 70 miles off the coast of Delaware. 
The ship is the Viktor Leonov , a 300-foot long, 47.5-foot wide ship equipped with electronic surveillance equipment as well as surface-to-air missiles and AK 60 rapid-fire cannons. 
Despite the seemingly close proximity to the U.S., a government official told Fox News, “It’s not a huge concern, but we are keeping our eye on it.” Advertisement - story continues below 
It should be pointed out that the U.S. territorial line stretches 12 nautical miles. Therefore, the Leonov is legally in international waters. 
This is not the first time the Leonov has been spotted close to the United States coast. 
In April 2015, the Leonov was seen near the coast of Mayport, Fla., the home of the U.S. Naval Station. Advertisement - story continues below 
There have been other instances in the past of Russian ships entering waters near the United States. 
In June 2016, the Russian spy ship Pribaltika was spotted near the coast of Hawaii while the U.S. Navy was participating in a Rim of the Pacific exercise. 
At that time, U.S. Pacific Fleet spokesperson Lt. Clint Ramsden told U.S. Naval Institute News, “The ship’s presence has not affected the conduct of the exercise and we’ve taken all precautions necessary to protect our critical information.” 
While the reason for the ship’s close proximity is a mystery, the ship is equipped with SIGINT, which allows for the interception of signals and communications. Advertisement - story continues below
